content.title: Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm Classification
content.definition: Classification systems for thoracic aortic aneurysms (TAAs) based on anatomic location, extent, etiology, and morphology, essential for surgical planning and outcome prediction.

ascending_aorta.boundaries: Aortic annulus to innominate artery origin

aortic_arch.boundaries: Innominate artery to left subclavian artery
zones: Zone 1: Between innominate and left carotid
Zone 2: Between left carotid and left subclavian

type_I.extent: Left subclavian to above renal arteries

type_V.extent: T6 level to above renal arteries

morphologic_classification.saccular: Focal outpouching, higher rupture risk per diameter
morphologic_classification.pseudoaneurysm: Contained rupture with discontinuity of all three layers

etiologic_classification.post_dissection: Chronic Type B dissection with aneurysmal degeneration

content.statement: Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm Classification is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Thoracic-Aortic-Aneurysm that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

learning_objectives: Apply anatomic location classification for surgical planning
Use Crawford classification for thoracoabdominal aneurysm risk stratification
Differentiate morphologic types and their clinical implications
clinical_pearls: Crawford Type II TAAA has highest paraplegia risk - discuss with patients preoperatively
Saccular morphology may warrant earlier intervention due to higher rupture risk
Zone classification determines endovascular eligibility and debranching requirements
common_misconceptions: Misconception: All TAAs require the same surgical approach - Reality: Anatomic extent determines operative strategy
